repository.corpname: M.E. Grenander Department of Special Collections & Archives

did.abstract: The International Typographical Union was a trade union for the printing trade for newspapers and other media. This collection contains proceedings, programs and photographs of the annual meetings and conventions.
did.physloc: The materials are located onsite in the department.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The International Typographical Union (ITU) was founded on May 3, 1852 in New York City. The ITU was a U.S. trade union for the printing trade for newspapers and other media. The original group had 14 cities that were split up into local unions. The first union was in Indianapolis. The ITU also had chapters in Canada. To be a member of the union, a person had to be a mailer or a newspaper writer. The ITU supported a variety of strikes including boycotting the Lost Angeles Times. However, some riots turned violent. On October 1, 1910, James B. Mc Namara, a member of the ITU and his brother placed a bomb in the Lost Angeles Times building. While the brothers were convicted, the Lost Angeles Times remained a non-union shop and continued to not support the ITU.

Members of the ITU supported an eight-hour work day, and joined other AFL unions during the Great Depression to support organizing. Eventually, due to advancement in technologies, the ITU was not financially stable enough to stand on its own, so members began to try and merge with unions like the Newspaper Guild and the International Brotherhood of Teamsters. These mergers however, failed and on December 31, 1986 the ITU dissolved. Members joined the Communication Workers of America.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection contains proceedings, souvenirs/programs and photographs of the annual meetings and conventions.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is uarranged chronologically. There are no series.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The records of the International Typographical Union were donated to the M.E. Grenander Department of Special Collections and Archives in two accessions. The provenance of the earlier accession is unknown. Mary Ann Darnaby donated all the convention souvenirs/programs in 2025. They belonged to her husband's great-grandfather who was a member of ITU #1 in Indianapolis, working at Hollenbeck Press.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Access to this collection is unrestricted.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The researcher assumes full responsibility for conforming with the laws of copyright. Whenever possible, the M.E. Grenander Department of Special Collections and Archives will provide information about copyright owners and other restrictions, but the legal determination ultimately rests with the researcher. Requests for permission to publish material from this collection should be discussed with the Head of Special Collections and Archives.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Preferred citation for this material is as follows: Identification of specific item, series, box, folder, International Typographical Union Papers, 1870-1936. M.E. Grenander Department of Special Collections and Archives, University Libraries, University at Albany, State University of New York (hereafter referred to as the ITU Papers).
